4.65.text:
PAUL JAY: Welcome to The Real News Network.
I'm Paul Jay in Baltimore.

8.22.text:
In 1997, Annie Machon, a member of MI5 British
intelligence left the intelligence agencies,

14.96.text:
blowing the whistle, alongside her partner,
for what she said was corruption, incompetence,

20.86.text:
and illegality. She's now a writer, a media
commentator, a public speaker on a variety

27.24.text:
of intelligence-related issues. She's also
the director of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition,

32.83.text:
or LEAP, in Europe. She now joins us to tell
us her story. Thanks very much for joining

38.85.text:
JAY: So give us a little bit of background.
How do you get into MI5 in the first place?

44.64.text:
MACHON: I was recruited at the end of the
Cold War. They were looking for a new generation

47.93.text:
of counterterrorism officers, moving away
from the old political work they'd been doing

51.32.text:
up until that point. And they also at that
point had just been put on a legal footing

55.69.text:
for the very first time in their 80-year history.
So they reassured me that they had to obey

60.22.text: the law, just like the rest of us.

62.48.text:
JAY: What do you mean, for the first time
in their history on a legal footing?

65.07.text:
MACHON: Well, they were established in 1909,
and until 1989 they didn't officially exist.

69.78.text:
There was no oversight. No member of Parliament
could ever question what they got up to. They

74.71.text:
could do what they wanted. In fact, Peter
Wright, the 1980s author of Spycatcher, said

79.30.text:
notably that they could bug and burgle their
way around London with impunity. So--and they

84.00.text: JAY: And MI5 is the domestic service.

86.05.text:
MACHON: That's right, yes. And MI6 is the
international service, like the CIA. And we

90.70.text:
also have a listening post as well. So we
got three key--.

92.88.text:
JAY: So a domestic service above the law,
not just the international service above the

97.17.text:
law, which was sort of the culture here for
the longest time.

99.25.text:
MACHON: Yeah, no, the domestic service could
do what they want, and they did. In fact,

102.36.text:
they investigated almost a million U.K. citizens
purely for their political activity, and not

107.56.text:
only the citizens: they also had files, secret
files, on a number of government ministers

111.66.text:
in the 1990s. And they did this because it
was the Labour government and some of those

115.19.text:
ministers in their youth had been involved
in left-wing politics. So, yeah, it was--it's

120.22.text: a strange situation where you have the spies--.

121.32.text:
JAY: This is all justified first of all by
the Second World War, and then the Cold War.

124.56.text:
MACHON: Yes, very much so, and they got very
paranoid about penetration of Soviet moles.

128.32.text:
JAY: Well, they did such a good job kicking
them out.

130.37.text:
MACHON: Exactly, yeah, exactly. So that gave
them justification to investigate what they

135.74.text:

MACHON: MI5 should have been investigating

course, all these people who were the Soviet

of them was ever prosecuted. They were allowed

158.43.text:
JAY: Okay. So jump us up to you get recruited.

162.80.text:
MACHON: I actually started working there in

168.43.text:

173.39.text:

181.57.text:
in a democracy where the spies have secret
information on people who are supposed to

185.95.text:

tail-wagging-the-dog situation.

188.72.text: JAY: A bit of what Hoover did in the FBI here.

190.72.text:
MACHON: Very much so. I mean, less cross-dressing,
though, within MI5.

193.29.text: JAY: As far as you know.

195.16.text:
MACHON: As far as we know. Then I worked against

very well known whistleblower in the late

221.08.text:
recruitment, saying that they didn't do political

222.66.text: JAY: What do you mean by political work?

224.86.text:
MACHON: Looking at subversives, people who

228.51.text:
JAY: So investigating people simply 'cause

231.04.text:
MACHON: Exactly. And when I say investigating,

234.66.text:
put bugs in their properties, they could bug
their phones, they could follow them around,

238.05.text:
they could send undercover people in to report

241.29.text:
MACHON: Oh, tiny little Trotskyist groups,
things like--they were called "militant tendency"

MACHON: Well, indeed. It was illegal to do

MACHON: Well, quite. So this was a problem.
They were shutting down the section. So at

262.69.text:
least that sort of stopped in the mid 1990s.
Unfortunately, then the role of spying on

left-wing groups was taken over by the secret

274.58.text:
JAY: It sounds a bit like some of the discussions

291.19.text:
I mean, everybody knows it's not a threat,
but you keep saying it is, 'cause you keep

296.10.text:
MACHON: It's jobs for the boys, very much.
And as the Cold War drew to an end and the

300.25.text:
Berlin Wall came down, suddenly the MI5 was

304.86.text:
when they focused on the IRA, the provisional
IRA in Northern Ireland. They took that work

308.90.text:
off the police. And that's what I thought

312.43.text:
officer. And, in fact, my second posting was

316.13.text:
And David also moved into T Branch, as it
was called, and then moved into G Branch,

320.32.text:
which was international. And we saw a sort
of escalation of issues that troubled us in

326.18.text:
both those sections. I mean, certainly in

330.50.text:
have been prevented by MI5 were detonated

335.69.text:
MI5 would then lie to government to cover

341.47.text:
JAY: I mean, sometimes there's been some suggestion

348.02.text:
sometimes it's not so bad if a bomb goes off
here or there, 'cause it again justifies even

352.43.text:
more effort to stop such things. Any whiff

356.62.text:
MACHON: There's certainly a whiff, yes. And,
of course, when they were working against

359.81.text:
the IRA, it was very different from working
against al-Qaeda, because the IRA had a system

364.04.text:
of issuing passwords, codewords before an
explosion. So they were quite sophisticated

370.92.text:
in their PR offensive. They would put a bomb
down and then warn the police so that nobody

374.61.text:
would get hurt, so they'd just have sort of
the PR hit of the bomb detonating. So, yes,

380.85.text:
I think some of that might have happened as
well.

383.59.text:
But it was really in the third posting that
we saw the major issues. There was, first

387.71.text:
of all, an illegal telephone tap on a very
famous left-wing journalist in the U.K. on

392.17.text:
The Guardian newspaper. There was also the
imprisoning and the conviction of two innocent

397.28.text:
people for conspiracy to bomb the Israeli
embassy in 1994 in London, and MI5 had evidence

402.93.text:
that they were innocent, and still let them
go ahead and be convicted.

406.68.text:
MACHON: Why? That's a very good question,
because MI5's assessment, after they'd looked

410.88.text:
at all the evidence around this case, was
that Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency,

415.18.text:
had carried out a controlled explosion outside
their own embassy in order to, one, increase

420.10.text:
the security around all their interests in
London--which they'd been pushing for for

423.70.text:
years, and MI5 kept telling them to, you know,
take a hike--and also to frame these two innocent

429.60.text:
people who were involved in Palestinian support
networks in London. And that network was gaining

434.65.text:
a lot of traction politically and financially.
And, of course, once you finger two innocent

439.62.text: people, the whole network just disappeared.

441.45.text:
JAY: So you're saying this as if you know
this to be true. Has this evidence risen to

447.89.text: the public level? Has anything happened?

449.20.text:
MACHON: Oh, absolutely. I mean, during the
whistleblowing years, this was one of the

451.67.text:
things that came out. And there was indeed
an appeal for the two people in prison. And

457.15.text:
they admitted that there were documents within
MI5, but they weren't going to disclose them,

461.76.text:
because they didn't have to under the secrecy
laws. So the two people who had to finish

465.49.text:
their sentences, they got 20 years in prison
each.

468.72.text: MACHON: Yeah. So the judge went against all--.

470.58.text: JAY: They did most of 20 years?

471.45.text: MACHON: They did most of 20 years.

473.28.text:
MACHON: It was a young woman called Samar
Alami and a young man called Jawad Botmeh.

475.79.text:
And there was a huge campaign to release them
and everything. It was a big, big scandal.

482.22.text:
But the judge just ignored all case law and
let them rot in prison.

486.54.text:
JAY: Alright. So was that one of the things
that starts to inspire you that this is--I

492.05.text: can't live with myself doing this?

493.73.text:
MACHON: Pretty much, yes. I mean, it was a
sort of process of boiling the frog when we

497.09.text: were in MI5. Things got worse and worse.

498.70.text:
JAY: So when's the moment you look around
and say, okay, I'm turning into frog's legs?

502.62.text:
MACHON: Well, that sort of came to a head,
came to the boil in 1995, because David Shayler,

508.71.text:
my partner at the time, was the head of the
living section in MI5. And he had an unusually

513.42.text:
close working relationship with his counterpart
in MI6, the foreign intelligence agency. And

518.28.text:
he was briefed officially about a plot that
MI6 was involved in--and some of his colleagues

522.46.text:
were, too; it wasn't just David. And this

527.87.text:
extremist terrorists in Libya. And this group
had links with al-Qaeda, which was a known

532.65.text:
terrorist group even then, which MI5 was investigating.
And MI6 was funding this group. And what they

538.67.text:
were doing was helping to foment a coup against
Gaddafi. So the group--.

542.85.text:
JAY: But to investigate, they just, I assume,
could have phoned the CIA and asked, because

546.75.text:
the CIA had, certainly at the beginnings of
al-Qaeda, at least, something to do with it.

MACHON: Absolutely, yes. I mean, you know,
all the support they gave them during the

553.60.text:
Mujahideen in Afghanistan, no doubt about

They liked to think they were big James Bond

562.35.text:
something, I think. And also, the quid pro

group would seize power and then would start
building nice, lucrative oil contracts with

571.89.text:
British Petroleum and all the other companies.
So that seemed to be what they were after.

575.39.text: JAY: Yeah, it worked out really well in Afghanistan.

577.14.text:
MACHON: Yeah, I know. They never seem to learn
from history. They're doomed to make the same

the way up the management chain, but sort

talked big and did little. But then, in early
